Key Arguments: The legislation threatens democracy by enabling censorship of free and open discourse.
The government defining what is false, misleading, or deceptive undermines unbiased access to information.
Determining misinformation is subjective and reliant on expert opinions, which may not be infallible.
The bill empowers the government to pressure platforms to remove content and penalize individuals, which is seen as an overreach.
The legislation is compared to actions taken by communist regimes, suggesting it is a step towards authoritarian control.
Notable Quotes: Censorship of free and open discourse poses a threat to the safety and wellbeing of Australians, as well as to our democracy, society and economy.
To even think that one small group of people have all the answers and the power to veto facts and ideas to the contrary, is not only immoral, but is a dangerous threat to democracy.
This Orwellian overreach is greatly disturbing. Facilitating the removal of alternative views is a big first step toward keeping public thought ‘in line’. This is what communist regimes do.
